mn21:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
mn21:3.3: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing overly closely together with the nuns.
mn21:3.5: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:3.6: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:3.7: That’s how much Phagguna of the Top-Knot was mixing overly closely together with the nuns.
mn21:4.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
mn21:4.2: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn21:4.3: and told him what was going on.
mn21:5.1: So the Buddha said to a certain monk:
mn21:5.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot that
mn21:5.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot
mn21:5.7: “Yes, reverend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha,
mn21:5.8: bowed, and sat down to one side.
mn21:6.1: “It is really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been mixing overly closely together with the nuns.
mn21:6.3: if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in his presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:6.4: And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings.
mn21:6.5: Is that how much you’re mixing overly closely together with the nuns?”
mn21:6.7: “Phagguna, are you not a member of a respectable family who has gone forth from the lay life into homelessness?”
mn21:7.1: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you mix so closely with the nuns.
mn21:7.2: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.
mn21:7.3: If that happens, you should train like this:
mn21:7.4: ‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
mn21:8.1: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence,
mn21:8.2: you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.
mn21:8.3: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
mn21:9.1: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.
mn21:9.2: If that happens, you should train yourself: ‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will live full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
mn21:10.1: So Phagguṇa, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of the lay life.
mn21:10.2: If that happens, you should train yourself: ‘My mind will be unaffected. I will blurt out no bad words. I will live full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
mn21:11.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
mn21:11.2: “Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants.
mn21:11.4: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
mn21:11.5: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
mn21:11.6: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
mn21:11.7: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
mn21:11.8: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
mn21:11.9: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
mn21:12.1: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
mn21:12.2: Then a skilled horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
mn21:12.3: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants; I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
mn21:12.4: So, mendicants, give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
mn21:12.5: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn21:13.1: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees
mn21:13.2: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.
mn21:13.3: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.
mn21:13.4: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,
mn21:13.5: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.
mn21:13.6: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.
mn21:13.7: In the same way, mendicants, give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
mn21:13.8: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
mn21:14.1: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
mn21:14.3: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is sweet, even-tempered, and calm.’
mn21:14.4: Now, Vedehikā had a maid-servant named Kāḷī who was skilled and tireless and well-organized in her work.
mn21:15.2: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being
mn21:15.4: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger? Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
mn21:15.5: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
mn21:15.6: So Kāḷī got up during the day.
mn21:15.10: ‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you?’
mn21:15.12: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.
mn21:15.14: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
mn21:15.15: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
mn21:15.16: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
mn21:16.1: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
mn21:16.5: ‘You’re getting up later in the day—what’s up with you?’
mn21:16.7: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she blurted out angry words.
mn21:16.9: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
mn21:16.10: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
mn21:16.11: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
mn21:17.1: So Kāḷī got up even later in the day.
mn21:17.5: ‘You’re getting up even later in the day—what’s up with you?’
mn21:17.7: ‘Nothing’s up, you bad girl, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a rolling-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
mn21:17.8: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors:
mn21:17.9: ‘See, ladies, what the sweet one did!
mn21:17.10: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!
mn21:17.11: How on earth can she grab a rolling-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
mn21:18.1: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:
mn21:18.2: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’
mn21:19.1: In the same way, a mendicant may be the sweetest of the sweet, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism.
mn21:19.2: But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really sweet, even-tempered, and calm.
mn21:19.3: I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
mn21:19.5: Because when they don’t get robes, alms-food, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish.
mn21:19.6: But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, reverence, and worship the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish.
mn21:19.7: So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, and worship the teaching.’
mn21:20.1: Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
mn21:20.2: Their speech may be timely or untimely,
mn21:20.6: from a heart of love or from secret hate.
mn21:20.7: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.
mn21:20.12: If that happens, you should train like this:
mn21:20.13: ‘Our minds will remain unaffected. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of compassion, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
mn21:20.14: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
mn21:21.1: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket

mn21:26.1: If you frequently reflect on this advice—the simile of the saw—
mn21:26.2: do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
mn21:26.4: “So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice, the simile of the saw.
mn21:26.5: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
mn21:27.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn21:27.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
